message: Oh.. and what people use when they want to host personal projects!  Who do you use as a host and why?
I want some XMPP primer stuff, CouchDB, HTML5, Mobile Apps, Native Mobile Apps, and lots of UI/UX stuff... did I leave anything out? ;)
What topics do you want to see people talk about?
You say UI and UX stuff, anything more specific? There's a lot of ways you could go there.
@jeffboyus concerning hosts: I am rather content with using SourceForge on my current hobby project; however, looking from the outside Google Code seems very neat
@thesethery My brain loves UI/UX stuff right now...  bring anything and everything.  Would be great to get some of the designer folks on this as well.
@eralston join the git revolution, my friend. Github is where it's at. It's what google code and source forge wish they were ;)
"Git is a relatively mild slang term used in British English to denote a silly, incompetent, stupid, annoying, or childish person" wikipedia ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Git_(British_slang) )
@HenrikJoreteg I've heard GitHub is pretty good, but I do have trouble with the naming.  If I did like it then I would have to tell people: "You should go be a total git!"
@eralston And I believe the etymology is indeed from that term.

@adambrault Well, back in my day we didn't have all these gits running around.  SourceForge was the best we had, and we had to merge changes, across revisions, both ways, in the snow...and we LIKED it!
@eralston Linus Torvalds says of the project something like: "I'm an egomaniac. I name all my projects after myself. First linux, now git."

@eralston I used to think it was a cool thing just Rails developers were into, but it's really a transforming way to write and share code with others. Couldn't imagine doing what we do as a team without it.

@HenrikJoreteg Trendiness does play a factor given that a lot of people get into OS for mastery of a chosen, fashionable technology.  I wouldn't deny it and would encourage people to try to harness it, definitely
it's not about being "good" its about the fact that it's where most of the coolest new projects are being hosted. Which makes it a *lot* easier to get other people to contribute etc.

If my code lived on Google Code or sourceforge, odds are, no one would be using it. It's all about discoverability and ease of collaboration. The first time you get a really useful pull request is magical.
